Tackling Bad Coaching in Youth Football League

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-12-2010 09:57 PM

This is a story about my sons first year in football. I'll try to be brief but descriptive:

My son, Adam, is 8 and loves football. Adam was 3 when he was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. After resisting for a year, we finally gave in to his desire to play football. He loves it but admitedly has had some bumps and bruises. As his father, i was allowed to be on the sidelines to care for him during the games. I was very grateful. On the sidelines you see and hear things you wouldn't if not there. I clearly overheard a coach repeatedly cussing as he came off the field. This went far beyond the classics such as hell, damn, etc., Also from this same coach came frustrations such as "I give up" in front of the kids. Kids who obviously came off the field hurt with some sort of injury were quickly triaged by this coach and immediately sent back in to play risking further injury.

Injuries are part of all sports and physical activities. Mild language, I feel, could have been overlooked maybe. The defeatest attitude of "I give up" is not healthy for the kids to overhear. So I took it upon myself to address this with the Head Coach. The irresponsible coach was removed FOR A GAME but was still allowed to attend. During that game I noticed some of the same kids who get very little play time sitting along the sidelines but now my son, Adam, was joining them. By me escalating this matter, my son was apparently being punished with lack of play time or so it appeared.

There are volunteer spotters (parents who track the amount of plays each player is in the game). I had the priviledge of spotting the first game. Essentially it's confusing enough with constant substitutions to cause the spotter(s) to miss the game. At this age, each player should get a minimum of 13 plays each game. At halftime, after watching my son (and others) sit for all but a handful of plays, I decided to ask the spotters who still needs plays. "Everyone has all their plays", I was told. I was floored. My reaction I'm sure was disbelief but then I realized by the limited vocabulary of this spotter from the opposing team that I obviously upset him and was then hit with a steady barrage of being called a "dude". I chose to walk away.


For that minor incident I was reprimanded and barred from attending my sons next game. I was banished from the sidelines so now I can not give my son immediate care. If not for my wife, I would have sent this coach and league, our resignation letter a while ago. The head coach has stated through emails that he can not do this without the help of "the cussing coach". Both my wife and I were shocked that this head coach was essentially condoning this sort of behavior around small children. Although he hasn't returned yet to coach, I worry for the kids when he does.

I would be the first to admit, this isn't going to happen 100% of the time. All leagues and coaches are different. Each leagues goals and motivations are not win at all costs as ours seems to be. Anyone have advice and/or similar experiences??
Report Inappropriate Content

‎10-12-2010 11:31 PM

I don't really have any advice but as a teacher I congratulate you on looking out for the interests of young children and speaking up about questionable behavior. However, I'm not really a fan of organized sports for children that young and want to point out that one option is to walk away.

What about videoing the games in case there is a question of your word against theirs?

Pam

Diagnosed Type 1 at age 16 months, over 45 years now
Minimed pump and cgm since July '09. Metformin (insulin resistance), levothyroxine(thyroid), losartan (BP)
I have traveled cross country, and to Canada, UK, Kenya, Mexico, Jamaica, Equador/Galapagos islands, and lived in Egypt for a year.

Tackling Bad Coaching in Youth Football League

‎10-13-2010 12:19 AM

I agree that the cussing is not great but is not *nearly* as big a deal as saying "I give up" in front of a bunch of 8 year olds. I helped teach martial arts to kids for a couple of years not too long ago and that is the *worst* sort of thing you can say to kids that age as they will remember that more than just about anything else you tell them. Participation and effort and teamwork are all much more important lessons to learn at that age than 'winning' or 'playing time'. I ran into tons of parents who end up REALLY disappointed when their kids they've pushed hard through youth sports don't quite make the cut in college or lose interest in high school. I've heard people talking seriously about junior high kids 'working' towards college scholarships? Sorry, I know it's fun to read Sports Illustrated but give me a break. Unfortunately, I'm not exactly sure what to suggest you do about the situation since it seems like there's definitely an entrenched and seemingly cliquish group in that football league. Good luck though. Maybe switch to track or cross country? Some of the same stuff goes on but I think that it's diffused by the sort of style of the sport?
Report Inappropriate Content

Tackling Bad Coaching in Youth Football League

‎10-13-2010 03:07 AM

It's really amazing how wrapped up some of these coaches get during a football game where most of the kids are 8 or 9. I only have girls, but they were cheerleaders in their very young days and I heard a lot of unnecessary bad language from some of the coaches and observed too many "power plays" among coaches and parents, such as making kids sit out for various unfounded reasons. And I have seen 8-year-olds vomit before a game, while the coaches are literally yelling at the kids right in front of them.

What they did to you was really wrong. I can't imagine that they have the right to bar you from the next game, especially since at age 8, your child needs you there for safety reasons. What would they do if your son had a problem? They are wrongly punishing your son for a question that you asked. Unfortunately, it's probably better to just continue on, and if it seems like your son is still spending too much time on the bench, I would contact someone higher up in the league to let them know what's going on.

Good luck with this. I know that it is really hard to watch your child be treated unfairly, especially at such a young age.

Jeannie
Jeannie
Mom to 14-year-old Katherine, dx'd at age 7

‎10-13-2010 02:31 PM

The real point of my post was tell you about the total disregard for a childs safety who in our case may need immediate medical attention. I thank all who posted responses.



After talking to many of the parents, I learned that some had emailed the head coach with similar concerns about this coachs negative attidude even before I did. The children from those same parents are the ones usually not seeing action in the games. And even after these emails complaining, this head coach had the nerve to tell the parents that he needs this guy back.



In all sports for children we should not lose focus of the real goal and that's to learn, develop new skills and to have fun. Safety should always be a major concern.

Hi Pam,

Thank you for your thoughts and ideas. I do like the video idea. Now if I could just find that recharger...

Oh I would've walked away right after this happened but felt I would've been denying Adam time to play a sport he is crazy about even if it was not that much. Also my wife didn't like the idea of Adam quitting at anything. I was overruled!!

‎10-13-2010 03:28 PM

i hate to play devil's advocate here. now let me add i played highly competitve youth- college sports, and represented the U.S. youth soccer team, and played football as well.

now while some people may come off as harsher than nice have you considered the fact that as you said the only ones compaining are the ones 'not getting enough playing time'

now while i have my concerns on the i give up quote, words are words and in my personal opinion a lot of the problems we have is the over sensitivity to every thing and words in particular in how they pertain to our offspring.

i know when i was a youth trying to make a name for oneself, i would push myself past the puking point to push the envelope because next time it would be easier. i had oaches that were nice, not nice, smart, hickish, black white constervative and liberal good and bad, hell some even drank liquor on the side lines. all had something informative to teach i just had to figure what it was and some times just the adversity faced in dealing with ignorant people has taught me more life lessons than any sport. but again i am not to popular around here right now because i speak my mind but we all come from different places and if you don't like how your kid is being taught take him to the next town over or maybe try a new sport.

‎10-13-2010 11:06 PM

Ehtics and all of the B$ that goes along with youth sports aside, have you considered getting him a continous glocuse monitor? I believe that the Freestyle Navigator has a range of up to 10 feet. I don't use one, so, this might not be a good suggestion, but you would'nt have to be right on the sideline, if the field is set up in a way that you could be witin 10 feet of him while he's not in the game. Also, the Navigator says that it checks every 1-2 minutes, so it would be pretty quick.

Jason
T1 - Diagnosed 05/2006

‎10-15-2010 05:24 PM

jason_d (10/13/2010)
Ehtics and all of the B$ that goes along with youth sports aside, have you considered getting him a continous glocuse monitor? I believe that the Freestyle Navigator has a range of up to 10 feet. I don't use one, so, this might not be a good suggestion, but you would'nt have to be right on the sideline, if the field is set up in a way that you could be witin 10 feet of him while he's not in the game. Also, the Navigator says that it checks every 1-2 minutes, so it would be pretty quick.



Jason


Jason, the Navigator has not been in production for many months in the U.S. and people have been given money back from Abbott to purchase another CGM. There is some FDA involvement and no idea if or when it will be available in this country again. The range for Navigator is actually much more than 10 feet, my son still uses one.
Mary, mom to Michael and Melissa, both Type 1
Michael is an adult, living on his own and using a CGM and MDI
Melissa is also an adult, with an intellectual disability, therefore she needs lots of help managing her diabetes. She uses an Omnipod pump and Dexcom CGM
